IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: With a mission statement founded upon "Increase in Excellence", the College is consistently ranked among the nation's best private liberal arts institutions. Emory & Henry College is among the top 40 institutions in the nation that transforms students' lives, as noted in one of the nation's best-selling college guide books. "Virginia has no shortage of familiar schools with robust reputations. But Emory & Henry does the finest job of them all of producing contributors to society" (Oswald, Colleges that Change Lives). Among other top rankings, the institution is recognized for its service to communities through service learning and engagement. It has consistently received top tier recognition in the Washington Monthly, U.S. News & World Report, Newsweek and many other publications. Most recently, it was named a top 25 rural college in the nation by College Raptor.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Emory & Henry College is a learning community in pursuit of excellence, engaging a diverse group of well-qualified men and women in educational experiences in which students confront historical and contemporary ideas and issues, and develop the ability to think critically about all areas of human experience. These educational experiences lead to lives of service, productive careers and global citizenship. E&H strives to provide the highest quality education, combining tradition and innovation as it transforms lives and creates positive social change in our region, our nation, and our world.
IRS990.Desc: E&H College provided formal instruction and related academic support for 938 full-time equivalent students toward the fulfillment of Bachelor of Science and Bachelor of Art degrees in a variety of fields of study. The College's academic program is shaped by goals to develop the students' intellectual abilities, to strengthen their ability to think critically about ethical decisions and responsible actions, to evoke a commitment to serve others, and to nurture their curiosity through lifelong learning. Student financial aid was provided to most students through a variety of scholarships and grants, supporting the pursuit of degrees. Formal classroom instruction was provided by faculty members in small classroom settings. To enhance the academic experience for students, services were provided through the library, the Powell Resource Center (for academic counseling, career services, personal counseling, skill development, testing resources, tutoring, workshops, and academic accommodations for students with documented disabilities), the Ampersand Center, and the Office of the Academic Dean. Writing labs and quantitative labs were available to students on an ongoing basis.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Auxiliary services were provided to all students. As a primary residential campus, most students were provided housing and meals. The Mercantile continued to provide books, art and school supplies, medical equipment and essential grocery and health products to students for their convenience.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Various services were provided to students through many programs and offices, including intramural sports, general athletics, the Outdoor Program, spiritual life, the Martin Brock Student Center, Admissions, Financial Aid, the Registrar, the Student Health Center, the Appalachian Center for Community Service, the Bonner Program, the Centralized Student Assistance Office, and the Office of the Dean of Students. Most students received some form of financial aid through various scholarships and grants, providing the opportunity to pursue degrees. Campus employment and internships were made available to many students, providing financial resources and valuable work experiences. Many community service opportunities were provided through the Appalachian Center, the Outdoor Program, and the Chaplain's Office. The College's equestrian riding team continued to be successful, offering opportunities for students to gain expertise in the hunter, jumper and dressage areas. Riding is open to all students at Emory & Henry, regardless of their major or level of riding.

Form990PartVIISectionAGrp.TitleTxt: Dean of School of Health Sciences

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Part II-B, Line 1i - The College is a member of the Council of Independent Colleges in Virginia, Inc. (CICV). The percentage of membership dues that is used for lobbying is 10.82%.

The endowment includes over 400 funds, the majority of which supports students through institutional scholarships. A portion of the endowment provides support for academic programming through professorships, chairs, lectureships, faculty travel, research, and other program expenses. A limited portion of the endowment supports other miscellaneous programs and initiatives for the College.
Change in Funds Held in Trust by Others $26,686; Other $(159,046)

E&H College publishes the following statement, "Emory & Henry College does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, sexual orientation, or physical handicap in administration of its educational policies, hiring policies, admissions policies, scholarship and loan programs, and athletic and other school-administered programs. Emory & Henry College affirms the dignity and worth of every individual."

Part I, Line 6 - Emory & Henry College receives funds from the Commonwealth of Virginia through the administration of the State Council of Higher Education for Virginia (SCHEV) for student financial aid under the Virginia Tuition Assistance Grant Program. Funds are also received from the federal government through various programs, including Federal Work Study, Federal Pell Grants, Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants, Federal Perkins Loans, Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education Grant Program, and Federal Direct Loans.

GrantsOtherAsstToIndivInUSGrp.NonCashAssistanceDesc: Various amounts and kinds of grants and scholarships are awarded to recipients to assist with the cost of attendance at E&H College, while pursuing a variety of bachelor of art and science degrees. The cost of attendance includes tuition, books, room, board, and other living expenses.
Grants to faculty and students are awarded to aid with research expenses, travel expenses, and supplies and equipment to support academic research in a variety of fields.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The College maintains complete records for the grants and scholarships provided to all individuals. Those records indicate the criteria used to award the grants, documentation supporting the grantee's eligibility of the award, and substantiation of the amounts awarded. Documentation is also maintained as to when and how the funds are utilized. Where appropriate, periodic reports are prepared, summarizing the allocation of funds, and a reconciliation of the amounts spent for each grant and scholarship is completed. The College employs individuals whose primary responsibilities are to oversee the process of distributing financial grants and scholarships. The number of scholarship and grant recipients for the cost of attendance are tracked by the administrative system. The number of faculty and student recipients of research awards are estimated based on the type of grants awarded and the number of participants.

RltdOrgOfficerTrstKeyEmplGrp.TitleTxt: Dean of School of Health Sciences

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Housing is provided to the President of the College. The house is located on campus, is furnished for the convenience of the College, and is a condition of employment. Housekeeping is provided at the residence in all public areas, as it is used for entertainment and business activities of the College.
Real estate agents are utilized for the sale of real property.

The IRS only recently (December 2018) issued guidance for employers on the Fringe Benefits Tax, a provision of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) that requires tax-exempt employers to characterize the cost of employee transportation fringe benefits as unrelated business taxable income (UBTI), effective January 1, 2018.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The form is distributed to the President, and the members of the Audit Subcommittee of the Board of Trustees Business Affairs/Audit Committee for review and comments prior to filing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: All Board members, the President, and the Executive Council are required to complete a Conflict of Interest Questionnaire on an annual basis. The Questionnaire is designed to disclose any conflict of interest so that the Board can address the conflict directly and immediately. If at any time during the fiscal year a questionable relationship is identified, the Executive Committee of the Board will address it immediately.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Board of Trustees Executive Committee has the responsibility of reviewing the salary and benefits of the President of the College on an annual basis. A confidential performance evaluation is completed, and then reported to the full Board. The Executive Committee develops appropriate recommendations, based on the evaluation, for consideration by the full Board. Comparable data is compiled from peer institutions, and other standard college and university organizations and publications for purposes of determining appropriate levels of salary and benefits. The Human Resources Manager compiles comparable information in regard to the other officers of the college and the President makes adjustments as appropriate, and as fiscally responsible budgets will allow.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The College makes its governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and copies of the Form 990 available to the public upon request. In addition, the Form 990 is available for public inspection on a third-party website.
